moves.1. Nf3: The Reti opening, white attacks two central squares on the first move
moves.1... d5: Standard reply, since e5 is attacked by the knight. Also hits e4
moves.2. d4: Occupying the center with a pawn
moves.2... Nf6: Developpement, hitting the e4 square again
moves.3... e6: The Reti opening has shifted into some sort of a Queen Gambit Declined (QGD)
moves.4. Bg5: Developping, pinning my knight. Good move
moves.4... Nbd7: Here I was looking for a Cambridge Spring Setup, which is 1. d4 d5  2. c4 e6  3. Nc3 Nf6  4. Bg5 Nbd2  5. Nf3 c6  6. e3 Qa5, with equal chances from both sides
moves.6. e3: Supporting the d4 pawn, while freeing the white squared bishop. Good move
moves.7. Be2: Develops the bishop, prepares to castle
moves.8. Nbd2: Blocks the check, and develops the Knight.
moves.8... Bb4: Putting pressure on the d2 Knight.
moves.9. Bxf6: ? Gives away the bishop pair for nothing much
moves.10. O-O: Castling Kingside and breaking the pin on the d2 knight
moves.10... Bg4: Developping a piece while attacking white's knight
moves.11. a3: Putting the question to the bishop
moves.11... Bxd2: Probably not best, but I was hoping for 12. Qxd2 Qxd2  13. Nxd2 Bxe2, winning a piece
moves.12. Nxd2: He didn't fell for the trap though. Here I thought about castling, because I saw that 13. Bxg4 Nxg4  14. Qxg4 Qxd2 would have been good to me, but then I saw that castling was met by b4, which wins a piece for white.
moves.12... Bxe2: So I decided to capture first
moves.14. b4: Attacks my queen while expanding on the queenside
moves.14... Qc7: Retreating on a good square, hitting the h2 pawn
moves.15. Rac1: Puts his rook onto the same file of my queen
moves.16. b5: attacks my c pawn, which is pinned
moves.16... Rab8: Anticipating the opening of the b file
moves.17... bxc6: That is why; I am now occupying the b file
moves.19... h6: A pure waiting move, creates a emergency square for my king. I had no obvious breakthrough, so I had to wait. This move happens to be VERY useful
moves.21. e4: Now I understand; He shifted my rook away to break through the center.
moves.21... dxe4: I saw that after the mass exchange, I could take his a pawn and create a passed pawn!
moves.24. Qxc6: But he takes my c pawn, and create his own passed d pawn.
moves.25... Rd8: Stopping the d pawn, since white would have won the race
moves.26... Qb3: ! Forking the rook and the d pawn. The rook cannot move off the back rank, because Qb1 is mate in a few turns. Furthermore, his queen can't protect the his rook and his pawn at the same time
moves.27. Re1: ? Moves the rook out of the line of fire, but it may not be the best move
moves.27... Rxd5: Taking the pawn, and setting up a deadly trap. I wonder if Qxd5 was safer though...
moves.28. Qe8+: ? This moves seem to win a pawn, but...
moves.28... Kh7: forced, it is not a mate because of my ''waiting move''
moves.29. Qxf7: ?? Immediately loses the game. Can you find the winning move for black?
moves.29... Re5: !! BAM! This is a great double sacrifice which wins the game. White resigned here. 30. Rxe5 is met by Qd1 (or Qb1) with mate next turn, and 30. Qxb3 is met by Rxe1 mate. Any other moves simply loses the queen, with a hopeless endgame. This tactic has been possible due to the weakness of white's back rank. Feel free to comment and rate.
